sen.j: 光格天皇（こうかくてんのう、明和8年8月15日（1771年9月23日） - 天保11年11月18日（1840年12月11日））は、江戸時代の第119代天皇（在位：安永8年11月9日（1779年12月16日） - 文化14年3月22日（1817年5月7日））。
sen.e: Emperor Kokaku (September 23rd, 1771 - December 11th, 1840) was the 119th Emperor during Edo period. (his reign was December 16th, 1779 - May 7th, 1817.)
Emperor Kokaku (September 23, 1771 - December 11, 1840), the 119th Emperor, reigned during the Edo period from December 16, 1779 to May 7, 1817).
Emperor Kokaku (September 23, 1771 - December 11, 1840), the 119th Emperor, reigned during the Edo period from December 16, 1779 to May 7, 1817.
sen.cmt: 閉じ括弧を削除しました。

sen.j: 幼名を祐宮（さちのみや）という。
sen.e: His name from childhood was Sachinomiya.
His name from childhood was Sachinomiya.
His name from childhood was Sachinomiya.

sen.j: 諱ははじめ師仁（もろひと）、のち兼仁（ともひと）に改めた。
sen.e: His initial posthumous name was Morohito, later changed to Tomohito.
His initial posthumous name was Morohito, but later it was changed to Tomohito.
His initial personal name was Morohito, but later it was changed to Tomohito.

sen.j: 傍系であった閑院宮家出身のためか、中世以来絶えていた朝廷の儀式の復興に熱心であった。
sen.e: It could be due to the Emperor being from Kan in no miya family of collateral line, he was keen to restore the events of Imperial family which were lost since medieval times.
It could be due to the Emperor being from the Kan in no miya family of a collateral line, but he was keen to restore the events of the Imperial Family, which had been lost since medieval times.
It could be due to the Emperor being from the Kaninnomiya family of a collateral line, but he was keen to restore the ceremonies of the Imperial Palace, which had been lost since medieval times.
sen.cmt: 儀式をceremoniesとしました。Kaninnomiya としました（他の記事と統一）

sen.j: 朝廷の権威の復権に努め、朝廷が近代天皇制へ移行する下地をつくったと評価されている。
sen.e: He worked hard to bring Imperial Palace's authority back, he was accounted that he established the base of Imperial Palace changing into modern Emperor system.
He worked hard to revive the authority of the Imperial Palace, and it was said that he established the basis for the transition of the palace to the modern imperial system.
He worked hard to revive the authority of the Imperial Palace, and it was said that he established the basis for the transition of the palace to the modern imperial system.

sen.j: 閑院宮典仁親王（慶光天皇）の第六皇子。
sen.e: He was the 6th Prince of Kan in no miya Prince Sukeito. (Emperor Kyoko)
He was the sixth prince of Kan in no miya, Prince Sukeito (Emperor Kyoko).
He was the sixth prince of Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Sukehito (Emperor Kyoko).
sen.cmt: Sukehitoに修正imperial princeに修正Kaninnomiya としました

sen.j: 母は、大江磐代（鳥取倉吉市の大鉄屋岩室りんの娘）。
sen.e: His mother was Iwashiro OE. (a daughter of Rin IWAMURA of Daitetsu ya in Kurayoshi City, Tottori Prefecture)
sen.cmt: 大鉄屋→Daitetsu ya? [読み方確認できず]
sen.e: His mother was Iwashiro OE, a daughter of Rin IWAMURA, of Daitetsu ya in Kurayoshi City, Tottori Prefecture.
His mother was Iwashiro OE, a daughter of Rin IWAMURO of Daitetsu ya in Kurayoshi City, Tottori Prefecture.

sen.j: 即位の前日に危篤の後桃園天皇の養子になる（実際にはすでに後桃園天皇は崩御しており、空位をさけるために発表されていなかったという）。
sen.e: He was adopted by Emperor Go-Momozono, who was in the critical condition, one day before he enthroned. (In fact it is said Emperor Go-Momozono died already but it was not informed since there was an interregnum period.)

He was adopted by Emperor Go-Momozono, who was in critical condition, a day before he was enthroned (it has been said that Emperor Go-Momozono had already died, but that wasn't verified because there was an interregnum period).

He was adopted by Emperor Gomomozono, who was in critical condition, a day before he was enthroned (it has been said that Emperor Gomomozono had already died, but that wasn't verified because there was an interregnum period).

sen.j: 元々は、閑院宮家から聖護院に入寺し、出家する予定であったが、1779年、後桃園天皇が崩御したときに皇子がいなかった。
sen.e: Originally the Emperor intended to move from Kan in no miya family to Shogo-in Temple to become a priest, however there was no one to succeed the throne when Emperor G-Momozono died in 1779.

Originally, the Emperor intended to move from the Kan in no miya family to Shogo-in Temple in order to become a priest, but there was no one to succeed the throne when, in 1779, Emperor G-Momozono died.
Originally, the Emperor intended to move from the Kaninnomiya family to Shogoin Temple to become a priest, but there was no one to succeed the throne when Emperor Gomomozono died in 1779.
sen.cmt: Gomomozonoに修正しました。Kaninnomiyaとしました。

sen.j: そこで宮家から新帝を迎えることになった。
sen.e: Thus the new Emperor had to come from the house of a prince of the blood.
Thus the new Emperor had to come from the house of a prince of the blood.
Thus the new Emperor had to come from the Miyake (house of an imperial prince).
sen.cmt: "house of a prince of the blood"→"Miyake (house of an imperial prince) "に変更しました。

sen.j: 当時、後継候補者として伏見宮貞敬親王・閑院宮美仁親王と美仁の弟・祐宮師仁親王の3人がいたが、先帝の遺児・欣子内親王を新帝の妃にするという構想から既婚の美仁親王が候補から消え、残り2人のうち近衛内前は貞敬親王を九条尚実は師仁親王を推薦した。
sen.e: At that time there were three candidate for the successor of the Imperial Throne, Fushimi no miya Prince Sadayoshi, Kan in no miya Prince Haruhito and Haruhito's younger brother, Sachi no miya Prince Morohito, since it was decided for former Emperor's daughter, Princess Yoshiko to become Empress, Prince Haruhito was no longer candidate since he was married, Unisaki NOKOE recommended Prince Sadayoshi and Naozane KUJO recommended Prince Morohito out of two remaining candidates.

At that time there were three candidates for succession to the Imperial Throne--Fushimi no miya Prince Sadayoshi, Kan in no miya Prince Haruhito and Haruhito's younger brother, Sachi no miya Prince Morohito--since it was decided that the former Emperor's daughter, Princess Yoshiko, would become the Empress; but because Prince Haruhito was married and therefore not a candidate, Unisaki NOKOE recommended Prince Sadayoshi and Naozane KUJO recommended Prince Morohito out of the two remaining candidates.

At that time, there were three candidates for succession to the Imperial Throne—Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayoshi, Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Haruhito and Haruhito's younger brother, Imperial Prince Sachinomiya Morohito—but since it was decided that the former Emperor's daughter, Princess Yoshiko, would become the Empress, Prince Haruhito was ruled out as a candidate because he was already married; consequently, Uchisaki NOKOE recommended Prince Sadayoshi and Naozane KUJO recommended Prince Morohito out of the two remaining candidates.
sen.cmt: 文章のつながりなどを修正しました。Imperial Princeとしました。 Fushiminomiya、Kaninnomiya、Sachinomiyaとしました。The checker's revisions definitely improved the translation but the use of two semi-colons made this a little hard to read so I have broken it up by using em-dashes instead.

sen.j: 会議の結果、貞敬親王の方が年下で内親王とも年が近いものの、血筋が近い師仁親王が選ばれ、急遽養子として迎えいれられて即位する。
sen.e: After having a meeting, although Prince Sadayoshi was younger and close age to the Princess, Prince Morohito was chosen as he had close genealogy, he was adopted and succeeded to the throne on very short notice.

After having a meeting, although Prince Sadayoshi was younger and close in age to the princess, Prince Morohito was chosen as he had a close genealogy; subsequently, he was adopted and succeeded to the throne on very short notice.

After having a meeting, although Imperial Prince Sadayoshi was younger and close in age to the princess, Imperial Prince Morohito was chosen as he had a close genealogy; subsequently, he was adopted and succeeded to the throne on very short notice.

sen.j: 尚、この時に先々帝後桜町天皇は皇嗣継承のために伏見宮と接触、近衛内前と共に貞敬親王を推薦したが、貞敬親王が皇位に就く事は無かった。
sen.e: At that time Emperor Go-Sakuramachi who was in power for last two generations, had a contact with Fushimi no miya to succeed he throne, he recommended Prince Sadayoshi like Uchisaki KONOE, however there was no chance for Prince Sadayoshi to be a successor to the Imperial throne.

At that time, Emperor Go-Sakuramachi, who had been in power for the past two generations, had made contact with Fushimi no miya to succeed to the throne, whereupon he recommended Prince Sadayoshi as Uchisaki KONOE had; however, there was no chance for Prince Sadayoshi to be a successor to the Imperial Throne.

At that time, Emperor Gosakuramachi, who had been in power for the past two generations, had made contact with Fushiminomiya to succeed to the throne, whereupon he and Uchisaki KONOE recommended Imperial Prince Sadayoshi; however, there was no chance for Imperial Prince Sadayoshi to be a successor to the Imperial Throne.
sen.cmt: Imperial Princeとしました。「近衛内前と一緒に貞敬親王を推薦した」という文章にしました。

sen.j: 1782年、京都御所が焼失したとき3年間、聖護院を仮御所とされた。
sen.e: In 1782, the Emperor lived in Shogo-in Temple as his temporally Palace for tree years when Kyoto Imperial Palace burnt down.
Beginning in 1782, the Emperor lived in Shogo-in Temple as his temporary palace for three years after the Kyoto Imperial Palace burned down.
Beginning in 1782, the Emperor lived in Shogoin Temple as his temporary palace for three years after the Kyoto Imperial Palace burned down.

sen.j: また、1799年、聖護院宮盈仁法親王が役行者御遠忌（没後）1100年である旨の上表を行った。
sen.e: Also in 1799 Shogo in no miya monk-Prince Michihito issued a statement to the Emperor of En no gyoja go-onki, anniversary of 1100 years.
sen.cmt: 聖護院宮盈仁法親王→Shogo in no miya monk-Prince Michihito [e-tanzaku.com]
sen.e: Moreover, in 1799 Shogo in no miya (the monk-prince Michihito) issued a statement to the Emperor regarding En no gyoja go-onki (the 1,100th anniversary).
Moreover, in 1799 Imperial Prince (monk-prince) Shogoinnomiya Michihito issued a statement to the Emperor regarding En no gyoja go-onki (1,100th anniversary of the death of En no gyoja).
sen.cmt: 1100th anniversary of the death of En no gyoja)を追加して、説明を加えました。 Imperial Princeとしました。

sen.j: 同年、正月25日に烏丸大納言を勅使として聖護院に遣わし、神変大菩薩（じんべんだいぼさつ）の諡号を贈った。
sen.e: On January 25th in the same year, the Emperor sent an Imperial envoy to Shogo-in Temple to give posthumous name of Jinben dai bosatsu.
On January 25 of the same year, the Emperor sent an imperial envoy to Shogo-in Temple to convey the posthumous name of Jinben dai bosatsu.
On January 25 of the same year, the Emperor sent an imperial envoy to Shogoin Temple to convey the posthumous name of Jinben dai bosatsu.

sen.j: 天明の大飢饉の際には幕府に領民救済を申し入れて、北方での日露紛争の際には、交渉の経過を報告させるなど、朝廷権威の復権に務める。
sen.e: At the Tenmei Famine, the Emperor demanded the government to rescue people, on Japan and Russia conflict on the North, he let the government report the situation, he tried to restore the authority of the Imperial Palace.

At the Tenmei Famine, the Emperor demanded that the government rescue people, and in regard to the conflict between Japan and Russia in the north, he let the government report the situation, whereupon he tried to restore the authority of the Imperial Palace.

At the Tenmei Famine, the Emperor demanded that the government rescue people, and in regard to the conflict between Japan and Russia in the north, he made the government report the situation to him, whereupon he tried to restore the authority of the Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 父に太上天皇の号を送ろうとして、幕府と尊号一件と呼ばれる事件を起こす。
sen.e: He intended to give the title of ex-emperor to his father, this caused Songo (an honorific title) Ikken against the government.
He intended to give the title of ex-emperor to his father as songo ikken (an honorific title), in defiance of the government.
He intended to present the title of Retired Emperor to his father in defiance of the government; this incident was called Songo Ikken (conflict between the Imperial Palace and the Edo government).
sen.cmt: Retired Emperorに修正 尊号一件の説明を修正

sen.j: 多才で知られており、学問に熱心であり、また400年近く途絶えていた石清水八幡宮や賀茂神社の臨時祭の復活や朝廷の儀式の復旧に努めた。
sen.e: He was known as he had many talents and loved to study, he also worked hard to restore the events for Imperial Palace like special festival of Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine or Kamo-jinja Shrine.

He was known to have many talents and loved to study; additionally, he worked hard to restore the events for the Imperial Palace, such as the special festivals of Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine and Kamo-jinja Shrine.

He was known to have many talents and loved to study; additionally, he worked hard to restore the events for the Imperial Palace, such as the special festivals of Iwashimizu Hachiman-gu Shrine and Kamo-jinja Shrine and also to restore ceremonial rites of the Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: 朝廷の儀式の復旧 を追加

sen.j: 1817年に仁孝天皇に譲位し太上天皇となる（現在までこれが最後の太上天皇である）。
sen.e: In 1817 he became ex-Emperor after abdicated and passed the position to Emperor Nintoku. (Currently this was the last ex-Emperor in the history.)
In 1817 he became an ex-emperor after he abdicated and passed the position to Emperor Nintoku (thus becoming the last ex-emperor in Japan's history).
In 1817 he became a retired emperor after he abdicated and passed the position to Emperor Nintoku (thus becoming the last retired emperor in Japan's history).
sen.cmt: retired emperorにしました。 Ninkoに修正

sen.e: He died in 1840.
He died in 1840.
He died in 1840.
Anei (November 16, 1772) - April 2, 1782
Anei (November 16, 1772) - April 2, 1782
Anei (November 16, 1772) - April 2, 1782
Tenmei April 2, 1782 - January 25, 1789
Tenmei April 2, 1782 - January 25, 1789
Tenmei April 2, 1782 - January 25, 1789
Kansei January 25, 1789 - February 5, 1801
Kansei January 25, 1789 - February 5, 1801
Kansei January 25, 1789 - February 5, 1801
Kyowa February 5, 1801 - February 11, 1804
Kyowa February 5, 1801 - February 11, 1804
Kyowa February 5, 1801 - February 11, 1804
Bunka February 11, 1804 - April 22, 1818
Bunka February 11, 1804 - April 22, 1818
Bunka February 11, 1804 - April 22, 1818

tit.e: Posthumous name, Tsuigo, a different name
Posthumous name, Tsuigo, a different name

sen.j: 第58代光孝天皇以来、千年近く絶えてなかった漢風諡号選定を復活させ、「光格天皇」と諡された。
sen.e: It was a restoration of Chinese style posthumous name selection since 58th Emperor Koko, first time in one thousand years, he received a posthumous name 'Emperor Koko'.
It was the first restoration of Chinese-style posthumous name selection since the fifty-eighth Emperor Koko, and the first in 1,000 years, whereby he received the posthumous name 'Emperor Koko.'
It was the first restoration of Chinese-style posthumous name selection since the fifty-eighth Emperor Koko, and the first in 1,000 years, whereby he received the posthumous name 'Emperor Kokaku.'

sen.j: それまでは「○○院」という形であった。
sen.e: Since then the name was called 'something-in'.
Since then the name was called 'something-in.'
Since then the name was called 'something-in.'

sen.j: 京都市東山区今熊野泉山町の後月輪陵（のちのつきのわのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed in Nochi no Tsuki no Wa no Misasagi, enzan-cho Town, Imagumano, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto city.
The Emperor was entombed in Nochi no Tsuki no Wa no Misasagi, enzan-cho Town, Imagumano, in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed in Nochi no Tsuki no Wa no Misasagi, in Senzan-cho, Imagumano, in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City.

sen.j: 18世紀末から19世紀初めにかけての随筆『耳袋』の記述によると、天明元年に、ある大名に飼われていた狆の主人に対する態度が噂となり、それを知った光格天皇がその狆の忠節を認めて六位を賜えたという話が伝えられている。
sen.e: According to the description in an essay, "Mimibukuro" between 18th century to 19th century, on the first year of Tenmei, there is a legend that one dog was very royal to the owner, the Emperor Kokaku gave the sixth Court rank to the dog for his royalty.

According to the description in an essay, "Mimibukuro" dating from the eighteenth to nineteenth centuries, on the first year of Tenmei, there is a legend that one dog was very loyal to the owner, so in reward for that loyalty the Emperor Kokaku conferred the sixth court rank upon the dog.

According to the description in an essay, "Mimibukuro" dating from the eighteenth to nineteenth centuries, on the first year of Tenmei, there is a legend that one dog was very loyal to the owner, so in reward for that loyalty the Emperor Kokaku conferred the sixth court rank upon the dog.
